search_queries: credential management AND (agent OR workload OR service account) AND (automation OR continuous rotation) AND (2024 OR 2025)
secret sprawl AND (agent OR non-human identity) AND (mitigation OR centralization) AND (2024 OR 2025)
dynamic credential generation AND (runtime OR workload) AND (agent OR serverless) AND (2024 OR 2025)

downloaded_papers.title: Establishing Workload Identity for Zero Trust CI/CD: From Secrets to SPIFFE-Based Authentication
downloaded_papers.abstract: This paper addresses how CI/CD systems use identity credentials for automation. It describes transitioning from static secrets to OpenID Connect federation and introduces SPIFFE as a runtime-issued, platform-neutral identity model for non-human actors. Key topics include workload attestation, mutual authentication, and Zero Trust architecture foundations for CI/CD environments.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Directly addresses core NHI credential lifecycle concerns including SPIFFE, workload identity, automation, and the transition from static to dynamic credentials. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: Identity Control Plane: The Unifying Layer for Zero Trust Infrastructure
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper introduces an architectural framework that merges identity management across different entity types—human users, workloads, and automation systems. It proposes combining SPIFFE-based credentials, OIDC/SAML authentication, and automation credentials through broker-issued tokens. The work includes policy enforcement mechanisms using attribute-based access control, compliance mappings for FedRAMP and SLSA standards.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Comprehensive framework for unified identity management across human and non-human identities. Addresses policy enforcement, FedRAMP compliance, and credential brokering. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: Decoupling Identity from Access: Credential Broker Patterns for Secure CI/CD
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper demonstrates how credential brokers can separate identity from access in CI/CD systems. It explains how runtime-issued verifiable identities (such as those from SPIFFE) work with brokers to enable short-lived, policy-driven credentials for pipelines and workloads. The work covers practical design patterns including just-in-time token issuance, access policies, and cross-domain trust.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Addresses credential brokering, just-in-time credential issuance, and policy-driven access control for workloads. Core NHI credential lifecycle automation topic. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: A Novel Zero-Trust Identity Framework for Agentic AI: Decentralized Authentication and Fine-Grained Access Control
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper argues that conventional Identity and Access Management systems designed for human users are inadequate for AI agents operating in multi-agent systems. The authors propose a framework utilizing rich, verifiable Agent Identities built on Decentralized Identifiers and Verifiable Credentials. Key components include an Agent Naming Service, dynamic access controls, session management, and Zero-Knowledge Proofs for privacy-preserving attribute disclosure.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Addresses emerging challenge of agentic AI identity management using DIDs and VCs. Highly relevant to NHI credential lifecycle as AI agents represent a new class of non-human identities. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: Identity Management for Agentic AI: The new frontier of authorization, authentication, and security for an AI agent world
downloaded_papers.abstract: The rapid rise of AI agents presents urgent challenges in authentication, authorization, and identity management. Current agent-centric protocols highlight the demand for clarified best practices in authentication and authorization. This OpenID Foundation whitepaper outlines the resources already available for securing today's agents and presents a strategic agenda to address the foundational authentication, authorization, and identity problems pivotal for tomorrow's widespread autonomous systems.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Comprehensive OpenID Foundation whitepaper on agentic AI identity management. Addresses authentication, authorization, and identity lifecycle for autonomous agents. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: The Human-Machine Identity Blur: A Unified Framework for Cybersecurity Risk Management in 2025
downloaded_papers.abstract: This research addresses cybersecurity challenges arising from the convergence of human and machine digital identities. The author proposes a governance framework built on four principles: treating identity as a spectrum rather than binary, applying uniform risk assessment across all identity categories, employing continuous verification with zero trust methodologies, and sustaining governance throughout an identity's lifecycle. Organizations implementing this unified strategy saw a 47 percent reduction in identity-related security incidents and a 62 percent improvement in incident response time.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Addresses the convergence of human and machine identities with a unified governance framework. Directly relevant to NHI credential lifecycle management and zero trust. Published in 2025 with empirical results.

downloaded_papers.title: AI Agents with Decentralized Identifiers and Verifiable Credentials
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper addresses how LLM-based agents can establish trust with one another. It proposes equipping AI agents with self-sovereign digital identities using W3C Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) combined with W3C Verifiable Credentials (VCs). This framework enables agents to authenticate themselves and establish various cross-domain trust relationships through the spontaneous exchange of their self-hosted DID-bound VCs. The authors created a prototype demonstrating technical feasibility.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Implements W3C standards (DIDs/VCs) for AI agent identity. Addresses trust establishment and authentication for agentic systems. Published in 2025 with prototype implementation.

downloaded_papers.title: Zero Trust Security Model Implementation in Microservices Architectures Using Identity Federation
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper addresses security challenges in microservice environments. It proposes implementing zero trust principles through identity federation using industry-standard technologies like OAuth 2.0, OpenID Connect (OIDC), and SPIFFE/SPIRE. The research demonstrates that this approach reduces attack surface, ensures consistent policy enforcement, and enables multi-domain interoperability while maintaining compliance with DevSecOps standards for cloud-native deployments.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Addresses zero trust implementation for microservices using OAuth 2.0, OIDC, and SPIFFE/SPIRE. Highly relevant to workload identity and service-to-service authentication. Published in 2025.

downloaded_papers.title: Agentic JWT: A Secure Delegation Protocol for Autonomous AI Agents
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper addresses security challenges in autonomous LLM agents that make numerous API calls without human oversight. The author proposes Agentic JWT (A-JWT), a protocol that binds each agent's action to verifiable user intent and, optionally, to a specific workflow step. Agent identity is derived from a one-way checksum hash of the agent's prompt, tools, and configuration. Features include chained delegation assertions, per-agent proof-of-possession keys to prevent replay attacks and impersonation.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Novel approach to AI agent authentication using enhanced JWT tokens. Addresses delegation, replay attack prevention, and agent identity verification. Published in 2025 with proof-of-concept implementation.

downloaded_papers.title: Achieving Flexible and Secure Authentication with Strong Privacy in Decentralized Networks
downloaded_papers.abstract: The paper introduces IRAC, a novel scheme addressing limitations in anonymous credentials for decentralized networks. It proposes a flexible credential model using vector commitments, a decentralized revocation mechanism where holders prove non-revocation through gap-based verification, and strengthened attribute hiding via zk-SNARKs. The scheme enables privacy-preserving authentication without enforcing a global static attribute set or verifier-defined policies with credential presentation completing in approximately 1 second.
downloaded_papers.relevance_justification: Addresses credential revocation and privacy-preserving authentication in decentralized systems. Relevant to NHI credential lifecycle management particularly for revocation mechanisms. Very recent publication (December 2025).

dominant_themes: Credential brokering and just-in-time credential issuance

Shift from static secrets to dynamic, runtime-issued credentials
Integration of W3C standards (DIDs/VCs) for machine identity
Identity Control Plane as unifying abstraction layer

OAuth 2.0 Token Exchange and Workload Identity Federation
Credential brokers for just-in-time token issuance

research_notes.quality_assessment: All papers are peer-reviewed or submitted to arXiv in 2024-2025, representing cutting-edge research in NHI credential lifecycle management.
research_notes.geographical_distribution: Limited institutional affiliation data available. OpenID Foundation whitepaper indicates international collaboration.
research_notes.practical_implementations: Multiple papers include proof-of-concept implementations (Agentic JWT, AI Agents with DID/VC, IRAC scheme)
research_notes.standards_alignment: Strong alignment with W3C standards (DIDs, VCs), IETF specifications (WIMSE), and OpenID Foundation protocols
research_notes.gap_analysis: Limited papers specifically from US government institutions (e.g., NIST, DoD). Most research appears to be from independent researchers or industry whitepapers.
